name: Avoid storing passwords in the config files
description:
This rule will check if you have entered password in your configuration file stored in the connection string.
Current limitation: the rule only considers the passwords stored in the connectionStrings and appSettings tag of the config files.
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in config file
rationale: Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file in the connection strings allows anyone who can read the file to access the password-protected resources. Therefore it is a common attack vector.
reference:
CWE-260: Password in Configuration File
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/260.html

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10-2017_A6-Security_Misconfiguration

A6-Security_Misconfiguration
remediation: Username and password information should not be included in a configuration file in the connection strings as this will allow anyone who can read the file access to the resource. If possible, encrypt this information
remediationSample:
We should not store user information in the connection string. We should either use the trusted connection or use verious available encryption algo to encrypt the connection string 

more details are available about different security @ https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/connection-string-syntax
sample:
<connectionStrings>
<add name="ud_DEV" connectionString="connectDB=uDB; uid=db2admin; pwd=password; dbalias=uDB;" providerName="System.Data.Odbc" />
</connectionStrings>
.....
<appSettings>
<add key="ESBPassword" value="********"/>
.....
<add key="UnicelSA.Password" value="********"/>
</appSettings>
alternativeName: Ensure you don't store password information in a configuration file or a properties file in plaintext as this will allow anyone who can read the file access to the resource.

qualityStandards.name: Password in Configuration File
qualityStandards.description: The software stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.

qualityStandards.name: Broken Authentication
qualityStandards.description: Application functions related to authentication and session management are often implemented incorrectly, allowing attackers to compromise passwords, keys, or session tokens, or to exploit other implementation flaws to assume other users' identities temporarily or permanently.

qualityStandards.name: Sensitive Data Exposure
qualityStandards.description: Many web applications and APIs do not properly protect sensitive data, such as financial, healthcare, and PII. Attackers may steal or modify such weakly protected data to conduct credit card fraud, identity theft, or other crimes. Sensitive data may be compromised without extra protection, such as encryption at rest or in transit, and requires special precautions when exchanged with the browser.

qualityStandards.name: Sensitive Data Exposure
qualityStandards.description: Many web applications do not properly protect sensitive data, such as credit cards, tax IDs, and authentication credentials. Attackers may steal or modify such weakly protected data to conduct credit card fraud, identity theft, or other crimes. Sensitive data deserves extra protection such as encryption at rest or in transit, as well as special precautions when exchanged with the browser.

qualityStandards.name: Security Misconfiguration
qualityStandards.description: Security misconfiguration is the most commonly seen issue. This is commonly a result of insecure default configurations, incomplete or ad hoc configurations, open cloud storage, misconfigured HTTP headers, and verbose error messages containing sensitive information. Not only must all operating systems, frameworks, libraries, and applications be securely configured, but they must be patched/upgraded in a timely fashion.

qualityStandards.name: Security Misconfiguration
qualityStandards.description: Security misconfiguration is commonly a result of unsecure default configurations, incomplete or ad-hoc configurations, open cloud storage, misconfigured HTTP headers, unnecessary HTTP methods, permissive Cross-Origin resource sharing (CORS), and verbose error messages containing sensitive information.

qualityStandards.name: Remove development, test and/or custom application accounts, user IDs, and passwords before applications become active or are released to customers.
Remove development, test and/or custom application accounts, user IDs, and passwords before applications become active or are released to customers.
The application must not contain embedded authentication data.
